item.title: Utilize Open API 3 for the Faster Software Development Process
item.description: I’m enthusiastic to open source world. There so many great things and free to use in the open-source world. Let’s say Linux, Kubernetes, Docker, NodeJS, Golang, anything. And this ecosystem always brings new technology and solutions for the better of the world (Software Engineering world).

item.title: Today I Learned: Pass By Reference on Interface Parameter inÂ Golang
item.description: Back to the college days, I remember there are 2 ways to pass a parameter to a function. One passes by value, and the other one passes by reference. Both of these ways have a different concept and sometimes it brings confusion to the programmer.Â

item.title: Integration Test With Database inÂ Golang
item.description: Software testing is a process used to identify the correctness, completeness, and quality of developed computer software. There are so many kinds of software testing. Start from unit-testing, load-testing, stress-testing, integration-testing, UI-testing, e2e-testing, and many more.

item.description: I’ve some project stored separated in 3 git-host providers: Github, Gitlab, and Bitbucket. Because I was a low-profile software engineer, I use both in Gitlab and Bitbucket for the private repository and Github for public repository XD.

item.title: Today I Learned: Making a Simple Interactive Shell Application inÂ Golang
item.description: So today, I learn something new and a bit of basic thing in Golang. It was making a simple interactive shell. It was just a very simple application, but it kinda looks cool to make it.

item.title: Faker
item.description: Faker will generate you a fake data based on your Struct.

item.title: Saint
item.description:
Source code: github

Download

go get -u github.com/bxcodec/saint

Example

package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"github.com/bxcodec/saint"
)

func main() {


 arr:=[] int {2,1,3,5,6}
 var x int

 x= saint.Max(arr...)
 fmt.Println(x) // 6

 x= saint.Max(4,3,1,5,7)
 fmt.Println(x) // 7

 x= saint.Min(arr...)
 fmt.Println(x) // 1

 x= saint.Min(4,3,5,5,7)
 fmt.Println(x) // 3

 x= saint.Sum(arr...)
 fmt.Println(x) // 17

 x = saint.Sum(4,5)
 fmt.Println(x) // 9
}
